awd_titl_txt: Synthesis and Tribological Behavior of Metal Diboride-Nitride Coatings: Optimizing the Hard and Compliant Response
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this award is to develop mechanically hard and wear-resistant tribological coatings such that: (a) the coating process affords high conformality (i.e., uniform thickness everywhere within reentrant shapes); (b) the coating provides low friction, and low wear under normal operating conditions; and (c) the tribological performance is stable and predictable under extreme operating conditions, such as high load and high temperature.  Specifically, low-temperature chemical vapor deposition is used to deposit coatings of the transition metal diborides HfB2, CrB2, and TiB2 using single-source, impurity-free precursors such as Hf(BH4)4.  Alloying with nitrogen affords HfBxNy coatings that have a variable elastic compliance; alloying with Cr is used to enhance oxidation resistance; and multilayer coatings are synthesized to engineer the relationship between hardness and elastic response, which affects the tribological behavior.

If successful, the results of this research will have a significant impact: it will enable the development of advanced devices that are free of lubricants and which have excellent lifetime under aggressive operating conditions.  These include, but are not limited to, energy-efficient and oil-free compressors and microelectromechanical-based sensing and actuating devices.  Graduate and undergraduate engineering students benefit through involvement in the research.  Students spend summer time at Sandia National Laboratories, as well as have direct interaction with both Sandia and Emerson Climate Technologies.  The results are broadly disseminated by presentations at domestic and international professional conferences, by publication in upper-tier peer-reviewed scientific journals, by seminars given at university and industrial laboratories, and by news stories that discuss the work as well as the critical role of the National Science Foundation.

por.por_cntn:
The major outcome from this research was the synthesis and deposition of different hafnium diboride (HfB2) thin solid films intended as protective friction and wear coatings in applications such as air-conditioning and refrigeration compressors.  These films have shown to prolong the life of equipment and also offer the possibility of reduced or no liquid lubrication, which possess environmental challenges.  Furthermore, a characterization method based on the scratch technique has been developed that directly measures the shear strength of these thin films, thus offering a method of screening thin film (coating) performance.  Short presentations on the definition and significance of hardness intended for high school children and the general public have been developed.  Also, information on thin film coatings and characterization techniques that has been developed in this work has been incorporated in undergraduate and graduate classroom materials.

Further details of the outcomes are reported below:  (a) Hafnium diboride (HfB2), Hafnium boron nitride (HfBN) and layered HfBN/HfB2 films (using different low pressure chemical vapor deposition and annealing parameters), deposited on silicon and 304 stainless steel substrates were produced. The measured roughness and hardness values are similar to earlier published values, namely hardness around 30 GPa and reduced modulus around 250 GPa. (b) A much simpler technique, called static chemical vapor deposition was used to coat buried structures. The potential application for this technique is in miniature systems. A major advantage of this technique is that it is inexpensive and scalable. (c) Using instrumented microscale scratch technique, we measured the adhesion and shear strength of the deposited films. It was found that the highest adhesion strength of 3.5 GPa was obtained with the deposited at 350 oC and annealed samples, and the lowest for the as deposited films (1.1 GPa). All films have comparable shear strength values in around 4 GPa. (d) A computational model that uses cohesive elements at the film/substrate interface was used to simulate typical scratch performance and generated yield maps that can be used for design purposes. The model revealed that the distribution of stress field and the maximum pressure required for the onset of yield are strongly dependent on the interface strength, as expected.
